food pairing: Aged Ham on Pretzel Bread, Havarti, Cheesecake with Raspberries
description: Low in alcohol, refreshingly tart, and often served with a flavored syrup like Woodruff or raspberry, the Berliner-style Weisse presents a harmony between yeast and lactic acid. These beers are very pale in color, and may be cloudy as they are often unfiltered.

food pairing: Seafood such as grilled shrimp, Asian dishes like pad thai, and marinated chicken dishes.
description: Crisp and tangy with subtle citrus sweetness, low bitterness

food pairing: Saladas, sea food, chevre and fruit desserts
description: Usually clear in contrast to most other wheat beers, slightly tart and very refreshing.

food pairing: seafood and poultry dishes, salads, mild cheese, and sweet desserts
description: Notable clove and banana aroma from German wheat yeast. Fruity, cloudy, low hop profile.

food pairing: Roasted chicken, gouda, banana cream pie
description: The German-style Dunkelweizen can be considered a cross between a German-style dunkel and a hefeweizen. Distinguished by its sweet maltiness and chocolate-like character, it can also have banana and clove (and occasionally vanilla or bubblegum) esters from weizen ale yeast.

food pairing: Chicken and dumplings, manchego, banana bread
description: With flavors of bready malt and dark fruits like plum, raisin, and grape, this style is low on bitterness and high on carbonation. Balanced clove-like phenols and fruity, banana-like esters produce a well-rounded aroma.

food pairing: Pineapple ceviche, chevre, Chocolate Creme Caramel
description: Often known as cassis, framboise, kriek, or peche, a fruit lambic takes on the color and flavor of the fruit it is brewed with. It can be dry or sweet, clear or cloudy, depending on the ingredients. Sourness is an important part of the flavor profile, though sweetness from fruit may diminish the perceived intensity.

food pairing: Shellfish (Mussels), Mascarpone with Fruit, Rich Chocolate Cake
description: Historically, they are dry and completely attenuated, exhibiting no residual sweetness either from malt, sugar or artificial sweeteners.

food pairing: Pineapple ceviche, chevre, Chocolate Creme Caramel
description: Sweetened version of Lambic

food pairing: Salads, Creamy Cheeses, Vanilla Ice Cream
description: Fruit beer is made with fruit, or fruit extracts that are added during any portion of the brewing process, providing obvious yet harmonious fruit qualities. This idea is expanded to “field beers” that utilize vegetables and herbs.

food pairing: Beef Carbonnade, Mimolette, Pumpkin Pie
description: Overall, the style is characterized by slight to strong lactic sourness, and Flanders reds sometimes include a balanced degree of acetic acid.

food pairing: Oily and buttery seafood is a great match for these sweet and tart ales; lobster, shrimp, sautéed monkfish, Dungeness crab, and king salmon.
description: Fruity, malty, sherry wine like, slightly sour

food pairing: Beer Battered Fried Shrimp, Triple Crème, Baklava
description: is fruity, complex and often on the higher end of the ABV spectrum, yet are approachable to many different palates. Look for a characteristic spiciness from Belgian yeast and a highly attenuated dry finish. This style is traditionally drier and lighter in color than a Belgian-style tripel.

food pairing: Roasted Turkey, Triple Crème, Caramelized Banana Creme Brulee
description: Tripels are often on the higher end of the ABV spectrum, yet are approachable to many different palates. These beers are commonly bottle-conditioned and finish dry.

food pairing: Seafood (Mussels), Brie, Lemon Ginger Sorbet
description: Beers in this category are gold to light amber in color. Often bottle-conditioned, with some yeast character and high carbonation. Specialty ingredients, including spices, may contribute a unique and signature character.

food pairing: Tempura Fried Fish and Chips, Taleggio, Savory Bread Pudding
description: gold to copper in color and can have caramel or toasted malt flavor. The style is characterized by low but noticeable hop bitterness, flavor and aroma.

food pairing: play very well with both desserts and roasted meats, including beef tenderloin, filet, and even the other-other white meat, duck.
description: Complex, with a rich malty sweetness, significant esters and alcohol, and an optional light to moderate spiciness. The malt is rich and strong, and can have a Munich-type quality often with a caramel, toast and/or bready aroma.

food pairing: Apple-Smoked Sausage, Washed-Rind Cheeses, Milk Chocolate
description: ranges from brown to very dark in color. They have a malty sweetness and can have cocoa and caramel aromas and flavors. Hop bitterness is medium-low to medium.

food pairing: Leicester Cheddar. Pizza & Mexican Food
description: Low to medium maltiness, high hop bitterness, medium hop profile

food pairing: Roasted or Grilled Meats, Mild or Medium Cheddar, Apple Pie
description: Characterized by floral, fruity, citrus-like, piney, resinous American hops, the American pale ale is a medium-bodied beer with low to medium caramel, and carries with it a toasted maltiness.

food pairing: Bone-In Pork Chops, Miso Salmon, Rich Cheeses, Carrot Cake
description: high hop bitterness, flavor and aroma. Alcohol content is medium-high to high and notably evident with a medium-high to full body. This style intends to exhibit the fresh, evident character of hops.

food pairing: Barbecue, Medium Cheddar, Banana Pound Cake
description: American ambers are darker in color than their pale ale cousins, the presence of caramel and crystal malts lending a toasted, toffee flavor, along with the perception of a fuller body when compared to beers without such malts.

food pairing: Roasted Chicken, Fish and Chips, Firm English Cheeses, Oatmeal Raisin Walnut Cookies
description: Broad style description commonly associated with cask-conditioned beers. The light- to medium-bodied ordinary bitter is gold to copper in color, with a low residual malt sweetness. Hop bitterness is medium.

food pairing: Roasted Chicken, Fish and Chips, Firm English Cheeses, Oatmeal Raisin Walnut Cookies
description: Most modern bitters are softly malty, usually with a biscuity, nutty, or toasty quality.

food pairing: The malt flavors complement the fried batter, while the carbonation and bitterness help cleanse the fattiness from the palette. British dishes like Bangers & Mash and Shepherds Pie
description: This style is known for its balance and the interplay between malt and hop bitterness

food pairing: Variety of Meats and Game, Pungent Cheeses, Creamy Desserts with Fruit
description: Scottish-style ales vary depending on strength and flavor, but in general retain a malt-forward character with some degree of caramel-like malt flavors and a soft and chewy mouthfeel. Some examples feature a light smoked peat flavor. Hops do not play a huge role in this style. The numbers commonly associated with brands of this style (60/70/80 and others) reflect the Scottish tradition of listing the cost, in shillings, of a hogshead (large cask) of beer. Overly smoked versions would be considered specialty examples.

food pairing: Variety of Meats and Game, Pungent Cheeses, Creamy Desserts with Fruit

food pairing: Grilled Meats and Vegetables, Aged Gouda, Pear Fritters
description: American-style brown ales have evident low to medium hop flavor and aroma and medium to high hop bitterness.

food pairing: Roasted Pork, Steak, Nuts, Aged Gouda, Pear Fritters
description: English-style brown ales have two variations: a dry, roasted version that is said to have originated from northern England, and a sweeter, less attenuated brown ale variety that is believed to have gained favor in the southern portion of England.

food pairing: Roasted or Grilled Meats, Gruyere, Chocolate Peanut Butter Cookies
description: has no roasted barley or strong burnt/black malt character. Low to medium malt sweetness, caramel and chocolate is acceptable. Hop bitterness is medium. Softer, sweeter and more caramel-like than a robust porter, with less alcohol and body.

food pairing: Roasted or Grilled Meats, Gruyere, Chocolate Peanut Butter Cookies
description: Robust porters have a roast malt flavor, often reminiscent of cocoa, but no roast barley flavor. Their caramel and malty sweetness is in harmony with the sharp bitterness of black malt.

food pairing: Seafood (Oysters), Ham, Irish Cheddar, Chocolate Desserts
description: The emphasis on coffee-like roasted barley and a moderate degree of roasted malt aromas define much of the character. Hop bitterness is medium to medium high. This beer is often dispensed via nitrogen gas taps that lend a smooth, creamy body to the palate.

food pairing: Mexican Mole, Spicy BBQ, Buttery Cheddar, Chocolate Cake, Ice Cream
description: Malt sweetness, chocolate and caramel should dominate the flavor profile and contribute to the aroma. It also should have a low to medium-low roasted malt/barley-derived bitterness. Milk sugar (lactose) lends the style more body.

food pairing: Chicken in Mole Sauce, Aged Cheddar, Sweet Potato Cheesecake
description: This beer style is dark brown to black in color. Roasted malt character is caramel-like and chocolate-like, and should be smooth and not bitter. Coffee-like roasted barley and malt aromas are prominent.

food pairing: oysters, seafood and smoked fish.
description: Aroma: Strong, with pronounced fruity and roast character. Flavour: A full-bodied palate of roast, fruity character.

food pairing: Foie Gras, Aged Cheeses, Flour-less Chocolate Cake
description: Black in color, these beers typically have an extremely rich malty flavor and aroma with full, sweet malt character. Bitterness can come from roasted malts or hop additions.

food pairing: Roasted Lamb with Mint, Soft Ripened Cheeses, Pecan Pie

food pairing: Kielbasa, Jalapeno Jack, Coconut Flan
description: Toasted bread or biscuit-like malt aroma and flavor is to be expected.  A stronger version was served at early Oktoberfest celebrations and became known as Oktoberfest. Today, the festival’s version of an Oktoberfest is quite a bit lighter than what American craft brewers consider an Oktoberfest.

food pairing: Grilled Meats and Vegetables, Mild Cheeses, Almond Biscotti
description: Vienna Lager ranges from copper to reddish brown in color. The beer is characterized by malty aroma and slight malt sweetness.

food pairing: Salads, Mild Shellfish, Monterey Jack, Lemon Custard Tart

food pairing: The char of grilled meats will pair well with the caramel and toasty flavors of the beer
description: Malty balanced with hop bitterness and woody hop flavour
